prompt:
Am I in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for ending free friend rides in my car?
My friend always hops rides everywhere in my car. I fill up the tank and pick him up at his house and drop him back off safely at home. This past weekend he put 10 in gas because I forgot my purse home and yesterday he asked me back for it. He has ridden in my car hundreds of times without putting gas. Am I an asshole for saying find your way around in the future?
"""

Am I in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (I am in the wrong) and B for No (I am not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if they're an asshole for ending free rides for their friend. The friend has used their car hundreds of times without putting gas, but this time put in $10 when they forgot their purse. The user then told the friend to find their own way around.

Hmm. The key points here are about fairness and expectations. The user provided rides consistently without payment, but the friend suddenly contributed once. The user felt it was a small gesture since they forgot their purse, but the friend might have thought it was a one-time thing. Then the user ended the rides.

I think the user's action might be justified. If the friend had never contributed before and suddenly tried to do so, maybe the user felt it was insincere or a way to get out of owing something. But the user is now cutting off rides entirely. Is that fair? Well, maybe the user was tired of the one-sided arrangement. The friend's contribution could be seen as a new expectation, which the user might not want to continue. However, ending all rides over a single payment seems harsh. But maybe the user had enough and decided to set a boundary. It's a bit of a gray area. 

If the user was annoyed because the friend only paid once and then expected more, that's a problem. But if the user just wanted to stop the free rides regardless, then the friend's action might have been the catalyst. The user isn't necessarily in the wrong if they set boundaries, especially if the friendship was unbalanced. So probably answer B, not in the wrong.
